reviewText: This Holiday film is based upon Louisa Mae Alcott's book of the same title.  It is set in New Hampshire shortly post Civil War and follows a young widowed mother's determination to carry on with the rearing of her three children in spite of the hardships that come about as a result of the loss of their father in the War.  Things look pretty bleak nearing the Thanksgiving Holiday and the children, wishing to have a nice Thanksgiving Day dinner for their mom decide, without their mothers knowledge, to turn to their heretofore estranged but wealthy Grandmother for help in making their wish come true.  Not to give away the pretty predictable plot or ending, suffice it to say that there are plenty of unexpected surprises for everyone along the way.  Not one of Jacqueline Bissett's better known films but her acting is passable as the young widowed mom.

reviewText: There are not many Thanksgiving movies around, so this is a good one to add to your holiday collection.  The pace of the story is a bit slow, but it does not detract from the film.  It has a good message to it - especially for the Thanksgiving holiday.  Jacquline Bissett is very good in this movie.  The young lady who plays the main character (I don't know her name) is a very likeable character as she tries to heal the rift in her family.Thanksgiving seems to get lost between Halloween and Christmas, so it will be nice to have this on DVD to help keep the holiday important to my family.If the price of this DVD stays at $23.00 upon release, it is a bit pricey (which is why I gave it four stars). If it is priced lower, consider this a five star review.
summary: A good Thanksgiving movie - not many around

reviewText: When I purchased this movie I really wasn't sure what I would be getting.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The story is good about a mother raising her children in a rural area and she seems to be the nurse-at-large.  When her daughter writes to the grandmother, whom the family has not seen in years and there is conflict between mother/grandmother, things really heat up when grandmother shows up in town.  As the conflict gets resolved grandmother takes the girl off to Europe.  As a follow up to this movie, An Old Fashioned Christmas continues the story, which is also very good. Enjoy this one.

reviewText: 3 women, 3 generations, and the 3 actresses excel in what is already a good adaptation of a famous author's work. It's not "Little Women" by L.M.Alcott, but you get a lot of the feel of that book as well. There is confrontation between all generations, and love as well. It takes struggle, and a Thanksgiving climax, to bring it all together into the homey cozy ending that all love.My favorite was actually the middle generation, Mary (Helene Joy) who I first encountered over several years playing a similar roll, only in "Murdoch Mysteries" she is a full fledged doctor, and does the nasty autopsy work for solving crimes. In the Thanksgiving film, she's healing when the real doctor is unavailable. In both roles, she plays the tough gal, but with a secret softer heart. You must see those Murdoch Mysteries, also period drama.Daughter Matilda is played by Tatiana Maslany who does a remarkable job with the role, although not a novice in film. 2 years later she steps up to play Mary in "The Nativity", another film worth your while. Of course the intended lead was rich Granny Isabella, played by Jacqueline Bisset. She's nasty and then turns sweet. She is grande, and her costumes even grander, she being the richest person of the characters. She got all the fanciest frocks. The rest of the period costumes and sets and props were expertly done making this quite an enjoyable and nostalgic romp back into the past.A fun family film, good for all ages, and stunning camera vistas. Some 'making of' bonus was fun to watch also.SUBTITLES & CC ARE PROVIDED FOR THOSE WHO NEED THEM.Now I wait for Hallmark Channel's "An Old Fashioned Christmas" staring Billet again as Isabella and Catherine Steadman as the granddaughter. Where's that DVD, I query?
summary: 3 female stars make this a true Masterpiece

reviewText: This Thanksgiving movie is based on a Louisa May Alcott's short story. This movie like all Alcott's tales presents a family difficulty, then eventually there is a happy ending with at least 1 if not all the characters learning a moral lesson. The content is appropriate for any audience to watch, but very young children may have trouble with the plot.Little Womenis another Alcott tale which is excellent in this version. This movie again is appropriate for all ages.

reviewText: This is a great Thanksgiving movie. It reinforces the messages of the holiday--being grateful for what we have, not forgetting those who have helped us along the way, helping those less fortunate even when we don't have much to share, forgiving those who have wronged us, and being sorry and trying to make reparations for the wrongs we have done.The main characters are strong in their performances and even though the ending may not come as a great surprise, there are twists along the way.The dominant theme is the seemingly life-long strain between a mother and her adult daughter. Throw in a little romance, a disapproving neighbor,  sisterly jealousy, a scandalous past, poverty, scarlet fever, and a rambunctious little boy, all woven around the Thanksgiving season and you have a story that will hold your interest.In one scene the young widow accuses her mother of having married her father (who was quite a bit older) for his money and only had a child (herself) so that his older children from a previous marriage could not contest the will. This is said in anger in front of other people and is the only thing I can think of that may bother anyone. There is no foul language, or suggestive material. Overall a good family movie.

reviewText: This is a wonderful family movie.  I really love this movie.  If you love period movies in the realm of little women, this is the movie for you.  It is about a single mother struggling to provide for her family after her husband has died and her relationship with her estranged wealthy mother that never approved of her marriage.  They are brought together again by a daughter/grandaughter in a desperate attempt to help her family that doesn't know or understand the history between her mother and grandmother.  The story is a wonderful story of love and reconciliation and hope.  This is a movie for all ages.

reviewText: I have watched other Hallmark movies before but this one was a bit of a disappointment.  This isn't the first story of a daughter estranged from her mother, but this one is just a bit annoying to watch as we see this character, Mary played by Helene Joy who is otherwise a very talented actress.  I do remember her from the Murdoch Mysteries as the doctor, so I was a bit amazed that she was put in this role of a long suffering, martyr type who would allow her family to almost starve rather than ask for help.  Not only that she puts herself in harm's way as the only parent left who goes out to minister to people with scarlet fever and in fact contracts the illness herself.  Jaqueline Bissett as the mother/grandmother was stunning as usual.  The woman just gets more beautiful with age.  She brings some color, joy, and a bit of "stirring up" to this mix of depressed victims in this story.  The scene where she addresses the wife of a neighbor who is wearing black for sons that died some years earlier.  Isabelle tells her that she deserves to have some enjoyment in her life, get out of the widow weeds and have a party!  I could see this being a Louisa Mae Alcott penning because some of the Little Women characters are similar, like Tilly, who resembles Jo in her strength, independence, and love of writing.  The mother certainly is not Marmi because she is just dreary all the time, is resentful of her mother, and is almost angry that she is now left to provide for these children, and also make them all feel guilty for how hard she works.  I guess that's part of the lesson of the story to accept, forgive, take delight in your friends and family, and be thankful that life isn't much worse.

reviewText: From the stunning opening shots of snow in New Hampshire, I was hooked.  I had not heard of this story by Louisa May Alcott, and if you are a fan of Little Women, I can only predict that you will be thrilled to find this movie.  The acting is excellent, particularly the young lady who plays Tilly, and Jacqueline Bisset of course dominates the screen every time she appears.  Like Little Women, there is sorrow mixed in with the joy.  I imagine younger children will find it slow going, but I was mesmerized.  Two caveats - the sound quality is not always the best, and some lines are hard to understand.  Also there were a couple of times when I didn't quite understand what was going on, including the very beginning.  I did figure it out eventually, and it did not detract from my enjoyment of the movie.  It feels very authentic, and I look forward to watching it every year as a Thanksgiving tradition.
summary: A wonderful movie to get lost in

reviewText: 12/01/2013 9:34am  An Old Fashioned Thanksgiving (Spoiler)I saw this movie when it first aired  on the Hallmark  Channel, several times  and  I liked it very much. I just watched the DVD that I bought from Amazon. The film has very strong period setting with what looked like real snow not that fake movie snow and it felt  very cold, The film has a realistic feel in terms of the precarious nature of life at this time, in terms of obtaining enough food to eat, the proper clothing to protect oneself from the elements. If someone asks about your health, it's not a casual remark, you could get very sick in a matter of hours. Tillie, the eldest child, has a vivid imagination, setting up scenes, like little one act plays, commenting on the outcome for good or ill. The grandmother steals herself into their lives with money and  gifts, the widowed mother had rejected her mother many years before and for good reason. This film reminds me,  at times, of  "The  Homecoming,  A Christmas Story" with it's simplicity, amid the difficulties of life.
